the latest one

what happens when you try to boot ?

well, it starts loading some things, then it stalls in a sort of command prompt, but it is not because some commands like ls don't work. I tried to update the kernel from terminal, but I  did something wrong.
I just want to know if it is possible to overwrite / without affecting /home/
sure if /home is on a seperate partition
unfortunately, it is not. My netbook already had 3 partitions, and the last one is used for ubuntu :(
so I only have one partition for ubuntu
not possible then, I suggest you copy off your /home directories
I guess that's the only solution
ok, I'm no expert, so I have to make questions. Do I really need to create a partition for swap? is it really necessary?

the thing is that I have one partition for swap, one for the recovery filesystem (windows), other for windows, and the last one for ubuntu. I think I  am limited to have only 4 partitions onthe hdd, is that necessarily true?
if you use extened partition you can hav 16 - but you won't be able to do that while you'v got 4 partitions, you'd need to delete one
ok, so then I can use extended partitions to install several linux distributions? Is there any advantage on having primary vs extended partitions?
not really
I thought that I could only use primary partitions. Then, can I use extended partitions to install more linux distributions?
sure
thank you, just one last question, would you suggest leaving swap, recovery, and ntfs partitions as primary and formating the rest to other extended partitions, or can I include swap as extended?
research linux compatible devices,
also check at what kernel level they are supported at to make sure the ubuntu version you want to use is at that level
